intro: Haplopappus andersonii, commonly known as the Anderson's hairy pappus, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads. The plant typically grows in arid and semi-arid environments, such as grasslands and rocky soils. Its small, yellowish flowers are surrounded by a pappus, which aids in seed dispersal. Haplopappus andersonii is known for its hardy nature and ability to thrive in harsh, dry conditions.
